issues.description: Inner-artifact naming inconsistency in the problem statement: the UML diagram declares the class as "Course" (lines 63-74 in problem_statement.md) while the rest of the problem description, the template repository, and the solution repository refer to the class as "Lecture". This mismatch can confuse students reading the UML (they may wonder whether to implement Course or Lecture) even though the attributes and methods shown in the UML correspond to Lecture.
issues.suggested_fix: Edit the UML diagram in the problem statement to use the class name "Lecture" instead of "Course" (or otherwise make the class name consistent across the problem statement, template, and solution). This preserves the intended design and removes student confusion about which class to implement.

issues.description: The UML diagram in the problem statement declares the class as `Course` while the rest of the exercise (text, template repository, and solution) consistently refers to the class as `Lecture`. This mismatch can confuse students when they try to map the UML to the provided Lecture.java file and the tasks that ask them to implement a `Lecture` class.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the UML class name with the rest of the exercise by renaming the class in the UML from `Course` to `Lecture` (i.e., replace `class Course {` with `class Lecture {` in the problem statement). This keeps the problem text, template, and solution consistent and removes unnecessary mapping confusion.
